properties.description: NZISM v3.8. The New Zealand Information Security Manual (NZISM) details processes and controls essential for the protection of all New Zealand Government information and systems. This initiative includes policies that address a subset of NZISM controls. Additional policies will be added in upcoming releases. For full details on controls, please refer to https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document. This policy set includes definitions that have a Deny effect by default.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_06.2.5.C.01
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Agencies SHOULD conduct vulnerability assessments in order to establish a baseline. This SHOULD be done: before a system is first used; after any significant incident; after a significant change to the system; after changes to standards, policies and guidelines; when specified by an ITSM or system owner.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_06.2.6.C.01
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Agencies SHOULD analyse and treat all vulnerabilities and subsequent security risks to their systems identified during a vulnerability assessment.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_06.4.5.C.01
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Agencies MUST determine availability and recovery requirements for their systems and implement measures consistent with the agency's SRMP to support them.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_07.1.7.C.02
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Agencies SHOULD develop, implement and maintain tools and procedures covering the detection of potential information security incidents, incorporating: user awareness and training; counter-measures against malicious code, known attack methods and types; intrusion detection strategies; data egress monitoring & control; access control anomalies; audit analysis; system integrity checking; and vulnerability assessments.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_07.2.22.C.01
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Agencies that outsource their information technology services and functions MUST ensure that the service provider advises and consults with the agency when an information security incident occurs.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_10.8.35.C.01
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Security architectures MUST apply the principles of separation and segregation.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_12.4.4.C.02
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Agencies MUST implement a patch management strategy, including an evaluation or testing process.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_14.1.8.C.01
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Agencies SHOULD develop a hardened SOE for workstations and servers, covering several requirements detailed here https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-15020

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_14.1.9.C.01
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Agencies MUST ensure that for all servers and workstations: a technical specification is agreed for each platform with specified controls; a standard configuration created and updated for each operating system type and version; system users do not have the ability to install or disable software without approval; and installed software and operating system patching is up to date.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_14.2.4.C.01
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Agencies SHOULD implement application allow listing as part of the SOE for workstations, servers and any other network device.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_14.5.8.C.01
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Agencies SHOULD follow the documentation provided in the Open Web Application Security Project guide to building secure Web applications and Web services.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_16.1.32.C.01
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Agencies MUST ensure that all system users are: uniquely identifiable; and authenticated on each occasion that access is granted to a system.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_16.3.5.C.02
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Agencies SHOULD: ensure strong change management practices are implemented; ensure that the use of privileged accounts is controlled and accountable; ensure that system administrators are assigned an individual account for the performance of their administration tasks; keep privileged accounts to a minimum; and allow the use of privileged accounts for  administrative work only.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_16.4.30.C.01
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Agencies MUST establish a Privileged Access Management (PAM) policy.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_16.4.32.C.01
policyDefinitionGroups.description: As part of a Privileged Access Management (PAM) policy, agencies MUST establish and implement a strong approval and authorisation process before any privileged access credentials are issued.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_17.1.55.C.03
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Agencies MUST encrypt aggregated agency data using an approved algorithm and protocol over insecure or unprotected networks such as the Internet, public infrastructure or non-agency controlled networks when the compromise of the aggregated data would present a significant impact to the agency.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_17.1.58.C.01
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Agencies SHOULD establish cryptoperiods for all keys and cryptographic implementations in their systems and operations.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_17.2.19.C.01
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Agencies using DH, for the approved use of agreeing on encryption session keys, MUST use a modulus of at least 3072 bits.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_17.2.22.C.01
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Agencies using ECDH, for the approved use of agreeing on encryption session keys, MUST implement the curve P-384 (prime moduli).

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_17.2.24.C.01
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Agencies using RSA, for the approved use of digital signatures and passing encryption session keys or similar keys, MUST use a modulus of at least 3072 bits.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_17.4.16.C.01
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Agencies SHOULD use the current version of TLS (version 1.3).

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_17.5.6.C.01
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The settings that SHOULD be implemented when using SSH areoutlined on the NCSC website for this control https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-15978

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_17.5.7.C.01
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Agencies SHOULD use public key-based authentication before using password-based authentication.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_17.9.35.C.01
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Before personnel are granted cryptographic system administrator access, agencies MUST ensure the requirements for access are met.  For a full list see the control published here https://www.nzism.gcsb.govt.nz/ism-document#SubSection-16122

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_17.9.36.C.02
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Areas in which cryptographic system material is used SHOULD be separated from other areas and designated as a controlled cryptography area.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_18.1.10.C.01
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Agencies SHOULD keep the network configuration under the control of a network management authority.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_18.1.13.C.02
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Agencies SHOULD implement network access controls on all networks.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_18.4.7.C.02
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Agencies SHOULD develop, implement and maintain an intrusion detection strategy that includes: appropriate intrusion detection mechanisms, including network-based IDS/IPSs and host-based IDS/IPSs as necessary; the audit analysis of event logs, including IDS/IPS logs; a periodic audit of intrusion detection procedures; information security awareness and training programs; and a documented IRP.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_18.4.8.C.01
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Agencies SHOULD deploy IDS/IPSs in all gateways between the agency�s networks and unsecure public networks or BYOD wireless networks.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_22.1.24.C.03
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Agencies intending to adopt cloud technologies or services SHOULD apply controls to detect and prevent unauthorised data transfers and multiple or large scale data transfers to offshore locations and entities.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_22.1.24.C.04
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Agencies intending to adopt cloud technologies or services SHOULD consider the use of encryption for data in transit and at rest.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_23.3.19.C.01
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Where administration interfaces or portals are accessible from the internet, privileged accounts MUST be configured to use multiple factors of authentication.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_23.4.10.C.01
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Agencies MUST apply the principle of least privilege and configure service endpoints to restrict access to authorised parties.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_23.4.9.C.01
policyDefinitionGroups.description: For each cloud service, agencies MUST ensure that the mechanisms used to protect data meet agency requirements.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: New_Zealand_ISM_23.5.11.C.01
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Agencies MUST ensure that logs associated with public cloud services are collected, protected, and that their integrity can be confirmed in accordance with the agency�s documented logging requirements.

metadata.description: List of Kubernetes namespaces to only include in policy evaluation. An empty list means the policy is applied to all resources in all namespaces.
List of Azure Spring Cloud SKUs against which this policy will be evaluated.
Whether or not to return warnings back to the user in the kubectl cli

metadata.displayName: Status if Windows Defender is not available on machine
metadata.description: Windows Defender Exploit Guard is only available starting with Windows 10/Windows Server with update 1709. Setting this value to 'Non-Compliant' shows machines with older versions on which Windows Defender Exploit Guard is not available (such as Windows Server 2012 R2) as non-compliant. Setting this value to 'Compliant' shows these machines as compliant.
List of API Management SKUs against which this policy will be evaluated.
The list of allowed curve names for elliptic curve cryptography certificates.
Specify a supported Python version for App Service
Array with forbidden public IP addresses. An empty array is evaluated as there are no forbidden IP addresses.
The list of excluded API kinds for customer-managed key, default is the list of API kinds that don't have data stored in Cognitive Services

List of Kubernetes namespaces to exclude from policy evaluation. System namespaces "kube-system", "gatekeeper-system" and "azure-arc" are always excluded by design. "azure-extensions-usage-system" is optional to remove.
Public Endpoint Type for which to enforce the access check
Array with allowed public IP addresses. An empty array is evaluated as to allow all IPs.
The minimum key size for RSA keys.
By selecting this option, you agree to be charged monthly per Arc connected machine.
The required resource logs retention in days
The list of InitContainers and Containers to exclude from policy evaluation. The identify is the name of container. Use an empty list to apply this policy to all containers in all namespaces.
Mode required for all WAF policies
The minimum TLS protocol version that should be enabled. Windows machines with lower TLS versions will be marked as non-compliant.

The list of InitContainers and Containers to exclude from policy evaluation. The identifier is the image of container. Prefix-matching can be signified with `*`. For example: `myregistry.azurecr.io/istio:*`. It is recommended that users use the fully-qualified Docker image name (e.g. start with a domain name) in order to avoid unexpectedly exempting images from an untrusted repository.

metadata.displayName: Would you like to restrict specific IP addresses?
metadata.description: Select (Yes) to allow or forbid a list of IP addresses. If (No), the list of IP addresses won't have any effect in the policy enforcement

The source k8s object for constraint evaluation. 'Original' means only evaluate against the specific GroupVersionKind specified in the policy definition. 'Generated' means only evaluate against k8s objects generated by Gatekeeper ExpansionTemplates. 'All' means evaluate against both the original object and any generated ones.
Specify a supported PHP version for App Service
Label query to select Kubernetes resources for policy evaluation. An empty label selector matches all Kubernetes resources.

schema.description: A label selector is a label query over a set of resources. The result of matchLabels and matchExpressions are ANDed. An empty label selector matches all resources.

matchLabels.description: matchLabels is a map of {key,value} pairs.

matchExpressions.description: matchExpressions is a list of values, a key, and an operator.

key.description: key is the label key that the selector applies to.

operator.description: operator represents a key's relationship to a set of values.

values.description: values is an array of string values. If the operator is In or NotIn, the values array must be non-empty. If the operator is Exists or DoesNotExist, the values array must be empty.

metadata.description: Minimum version of TLS required to access data in this storage account
Enable or disable the execution of the policy
'Audit' allows a non-compliant resource to be created, but flags it as non-compliant. 'Deny' blocks the resource creation. 'Disable' turns off the policy.

metadata.displayName: Audit, deny or disable the execution of the policy
metadata.description: Audit, deny or disable the execution of the policy
Specify a supported Java version for App Service

policyDefinitions.policyDefinitionReferenceId: A vulnerability assessment solution should be enabled on your virtual machines
Vulnerability assessment should be enabled on SQL Managed Instance
Vulnerability assessment should be enabled on your SQL servers
SQL databases should have vulnerability findings resolved
SQL servers on machines should have vulnerability findings resolved
Vulnerabilities in security configuration on your machines should be remediated
Machines should have secret findings resolved
Azure registry container images should have vulnerabilities resolved (powered by Microsoft Defender Vulnerability Management)
Azure running container images should have vulnerabilities resolved (powered by Microsoft Defender Vulnerability Management)
Configure Microsoft Defender for Containers to be enabled
Audit virtual machines without disaster recovery configured
Azure Defender for App Service should be enabled
Azure Defender for Azure SQL Database servers should be enabled
Azure Defender for Key Vault should be enabled
Azure Defender for open-source relational databases should be enabled
Azure Defender for Resource Manager should be enabled
Azure Defender for servers should be enabled
Azure Defender for SQL servers on machines should be enabled
Azure Defender for SQL should be enabled for unprotected Azure SQL servers
Azure Defender for SQL should be enabled for unprotected SQL Managed Instances
Azure Kubernetes Service clusters should have Defender profile enabled
Microsoft Defender for Containers should be enabled
Microsoft Defender for Storage should be enabled
Microsoft Defender for APIs should be enabled
Microsoft Defender for Azure Cosmos DB should be enabled
Microsoft Defender for SQL should be enabled for unprotected Synapse workspaces
Azure Defender for SQL should be enabled for unprotected PostgreSQL flexible servers
Email notification for high severity alerts should be enabled
Email notification to subscription owner for high severity alerts should be enabled
Subscriptions should have a contact email address for security issues
API Management services should use a virtual network
App Configuration should use private link

Azure Cache for Redis should use private link
Azure Event Grid domains should use private link
Azure Event Grid topics should use private link
Azure Key Vaults should use private link
Azure Machine Learning workspaces should use private link
Azure SignalR Service should use private link
Azure Spring Cloud should use network injection
Container registries should use private link
Private endpoint connections on Azure SQL Database should be enabled
Private endpoint connections on Batch accounts should be enabled
Private endpoint should be enabled for MariaDB servers
Private endpoint should be enabled for MySQL servers
Private endpoint should be enabled for PostgreSQL servers
Public network access should be disabled for MySQL flexible servers
Public network access should be disabled for PostgreSQL flexible servers
Storage accounts should restrict network access using virtual network rules
Storage accounts should use private link
VM Image Builder templates should use private link
Azure Databricks Clusters should disable public IP
Azure Databricks Workspaces should disable public network access
Azure Databricks Workspaces should use private link
Azure Machine Learning Workspaces should disable public network access
Azure Cosmos DB should disable public network access
Azure Databricks Workspaces should be in a virtual network
Azure SQL Managed Instances should disable public network access
API Management should disable public network access to the service configuration endpoints
CosmosDB accounts should use private link
Azure Machine Learning Computes should be in a virtual network
Machines should be configured to periodically check for missing system updates
Azure Machine Learning compute instances should be recreated to get the latest software updates
App Service apps should have remote debugging turned off
Function apps should have remote debugging turned off
Management ports should be closed on your virtual machines
Azure Policy Add-on for Kubernetes service (AKS) should be installed and enabled on your clusters
Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) should be used on Kubernetes Services
Endpoint protection health issues should be resolved on your machines
Endpoint protection should be installed on your machines
Endpoint protection solution should be installed on virtual machine scale sets
Guest Configuration extension should be installed on your machines
Kubernetes cluster containers should not share host process ID or host IPC namespace
Kubernetes cluster containers should run with a read only root file system
Kubernetes cluster should not allow privileged containers
Kubernetes clusters should be accessible only over HTTPS
Kubernetes clusters should disable automounting API credentials
Kubernetes clusters should not allow container privilege escalation
Kubernetes clusters should not grant CAP_SYS_ADMIN security capabilities
Kubernetes clusters should not use the default namespace
Management ports of virtual machines should be protected with just-in-time network access control
Microsoft Antimalware for Azure should be configured to automatically update protection signatures
Microsoft IaaSAntimalware extension should be deployed on Windows servers
Monitor missing Endpoint Protection in Azure Security Center
Virtual machines- Guest Configuration extension should be deployed with system-assigned managed identity
Windows Defender Exploit Guard should be enabled on your machines
App Service apps should have authentication enabled
App Service apps should not have CORS configured to allow every resource to access your apps
App Service apps should only be accessible over HTTPS
App Service apps should require FTPS only
App Service apps should use latest -HTTP Version-
App Service apps that use Java should use a specified -Java version-
App Service apps that use PHP should use a specified -PHP version-
App Service apps that use Python should use a specified -Python version-
Function apps should have authentication enabled
Function apps should not have CORS configured to allow every resource to access your apps
Function apps should only be accessible over HTTPS
Function apps should require FTPS only
Function apps should use latest -HTTP Version-
Function apps that use Java should use a specified -Java version-
Function apps that use Python should use a specified -Python version-
App Service apps should have Client Certificates (Incoming client certificates) enabled
App Service app slots should have Client Certificates (Incoming client certificates) enabled
Function apps should have Client Certificates (Incoming client certificates) enabled
App Service apps should use managed identity
Azure SQL Database should have Microsoft Entra-only authentication enabled during creation
Cosmos DB database accounts should have local authentication methods disabled
Function apps should use managed identity
Service Fabric clusters should only use Azure Active Directory for client authentication
API Management calls to API backends should be authenticated
Storage accounts should prevent shared key access
Azure SQL Managed Instance should have Microsoft Entra-only authentication enabled
A Microsoft Entra administrator should be provisioned for MySQL servers
Synapse Workspaces should use only Microsoft Entra identities for authentication during workspace creation
Azure MySQL flexible server should have Microsoft Entra Only Authentication enabled
Synapse Workspaces should have Microsoft Entra-only authentication enabled
Azure AI Services resources should have key access disabled (disable local authentication)
Azure SQL Managed Instances should have Microsoft Entra-only authentication enabled during creation
Azure SQL Database should have Microsoft Entra-only authentication enabled
A Microsoft Entra administrator should be provisioned for PostgreSQL servers
Azure Machine Learning Computes should have local authentication methods disabled
API endpoints in Azure API Management should be authenticated
A maximum of 3 owners should be designated for your subscription
Blocked accounts with owner permissions on Azure resources should be removed
Blocked accounts with read and write permissions on Azure resources should be removed
Guest accounts with owner permissions on Azure resources should be removed
Guest accounts with read permissions on Azure resources should be removed
Guest accounts with write permissions on Azure resources should be removed
There should be more than one owner assigned to your subscription
An Azure Active Directory administrator should be provisioned for SQL servers
API Management APIs should use only encrypted protocols
Key Vault keys should have an expiration date
Key Vault secrets should have an expiration date
Storage account keys should not be expired
Keys using RSA cryptography should have a specified minimum key size
Keys using elliptic curve cryptography should have the specified curve names
Certificates using RSA cryptography should have the specified minimum key size
App Service apps should use the latest TLS version
Function apps should use the latest TLS version
Windows machines should be configured to use secure communication protocols
Azure SQL Database should be running TLS version 1.2 or newer
Storage accounts should have the specified minimum TLS version
IP Forwarding on your virtual machine should be disabled
Authentication to Linux machines should require SSH keys
Azure Key Vault should use RBAC permission model
API Management secret named values should be stored in Azure Key Vault
All network ports should be restricted on network security groups associated to your virtual machine
Authorized IP ranges should be defined on Kubernetes Services
Azure AI Services resources should restrict network access
Azure Cosmos DB accounts should have firewall rules
Azure Key Vault should have firewall enabled
Container registries should not allow unrestricted network access
CORS should not allow every domain to access your API for FHIR
Enforce SSL connection should be enabled for MySQL database servers
Enforce SSL connection should be enabled for PostgreSQL database servers
Internet-facing virtual machines should be protected with network security groups
Non-internet-facing virtual machines should be protected with network security groups
Only secure connections to your Azure Cache for Redis should be enabled
Public network access on Azure SQL Database should be disabled
Public network access should be disabled for MariaDB servers
Public network access should be disabled for MySQL servers
Public network access should be disabled for PostgreSQL servers
Secure transfer to storage accounts should be enabled
Storage accounts should restrict network access
Subnets should be associated with a Network Security Group
Azure DDoS Protection should be enabled
Connection throttling should be enabled for PostgreSQL database servers
All authorization rules except RootManageSharedAccessKey should be removed from Service Bus namespace
Azure Web Application Firewall should be enabled for Azure Front Door entry-points
Web Application Firewall (WAF) should be enabled for Application Gateway
Web Application Firewall (WAF) should use the specified mode for Application Gateway
Web Application Firewall (WAF) should use the specified mode for Azure Front Door Service
API endpoints that are unused should be disabled and removed from the Azure API Management service
Virtual machines and virtual machine scale sets should have encryption at host enabled
Accounts with owner permissions on Azure resources should be MFA enabled
Accounts with read permissions on Azure resources should be MFA enabled
Accounts with write permissions on Azure resources should be MFA enabled
API Management minimum API version should be set to 2019-12-01 or higher
API Management subscriptions should not be scoped to all APIs
API Management direct management endpoint should not be enabled
API Management calls to API backends should not bypass certificate thumbprint or name validation
Automation account variables should be encrypted
Azure Cosmos DB accounts should use customer-managed keys to encrypt data at rest
Azure Key Vault Managed HSM should have purge protection enabled
Azure Machine Learning workspaces should be encrypted with a customer-managed key
Azure AI Services resources should encrypt data at rest with a customer-managed key (CMK)
Container registries should be encrypted with a customer-managed key
Disk encryption should be enabled on Azure Data Explorer
Key vaults should have deletion protection enabled
Key vaults should have soft delete enabled
MySQL servers should use customer-managed keys to encrypt data at rest
PostgreSQL servers should use customer-managed keys to encrypt data at rest
Require encryption on Data Lake Store accounts
Service Fabric clusters should have the ClusterProtectionLevel property set to EncryptAndSign
SQL managed instances should use customer-managed keys to encrypt data at rest
SQL servers should use customer-managed keys to encrypt data at rest
Storage accounts should use customer-managed key for encryption
Transparent Data Encryption on SQL databases should be enabled
App Service apps should have resource logs enabled
Audit usage of custom RBAC roles
Auditing on SQL server should be enabled
Disconnections should be logged for PostgreSQL database servers.
Log connections should be enabled for PostgreSQL database servers
Resource logs in Azure Data Lake Store should be enabled
Resource logs in Azure Kubernetes Service should be enabled
Resource logs in Azure Stream Analytics should be enabled
Resource logs in Batch accounts should be enabled
Resource logs in Data Lake Analytics should be enabled
Resource logs in Event Hub should be enabled
Resource logs in IoT Hub should be enabled
Resource logs in Key Vault should be enabled
Resource logs in Logic Apps should be enabled
Resource logs in Search services should be enabled
Resource logs in Service Bus should be enabled
SQL servers with auditing to storage account destination should be configured with 90 days retention or higher
SQL server-targeted autoprovisioning should be enabled for SQL servers on machines plan
Resource logs in Azure Machine Learning Workspaces should be enabled
